critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer flash the white underside of their tails to warn others of nearby danger.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have excellent memories and can remember food locations for years!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can hear a mouse rustle up to 100 feet away, thanks to their excellent hearing!

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes can hear low-frequency sounds, helping them detect small animals digging underground for food!

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes can climb trees, a rare skill among canines, helping them escape predators.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats have excellent night vision, helping them hunt effectively in low-light conditions.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have nearly 30,000 sharp quills for defense, which detach easily when predators attack!

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using sticks and mud to create quiet ponds for safety and food storage.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, often floating on water for protection against predators!

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have dense, water-repellent fur that keeps them warm and dry while swimming.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can descend trees headfirst, unlike many other mammals!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to eight minutes while hunting fish!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can leap up to 10 times their body length between trees!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches to survive cold winters.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks can gather and store up to 165 acorns in their cheek pouches!

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails use their large hind legs to make quick, zigzag hops to escape predators quickly.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have incredibly nimble front paws, almost like human hands, helping them open jars and doors!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are immune to snake venom and can survive bites from venomous snakes like rattlesnakes!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can accurately spray a smelly liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide up to 150 feet using a flap of skin called a patagium between their limbs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects with incredible accuracy in total darkness!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big brown bats use echolocation to catch insects, making them excellent nighttime pest controllers!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees without harming blood flow!

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few warm-weather birds where males and females sing beautifully.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food during winter!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice use their crest to communicate mood, raising it when alert or excited!

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that only go upwards.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers use their small, chisel-like beaks to tap trees and find insects to eat.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and find insects beneath tree bark.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large, rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers use their strong beaks to drum on trees, communicating and finding insects!

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 mph, making them one of North Americaâ€™s fastest birds!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinch molt twice yearly, brightening their feathers in spring for courtship and turning dull in fall.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear during winter across North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches were originally found only in the western U.S. but now thrive across North America!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches sing sweet, melodious songs to mark their territory and attract mates during springtime.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances at 55 mph!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by rapidly beating their wings to attract mates and defend territory!

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes dance to communicate, showing off their strength and forming strong pair bonds for life!

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember those who have threatened them before.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech, making them clever and entertaining birds to watch!

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks have excellent eyesight, spotting small prey from over a mile away while soaring high!

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are expert flyers, weaving swiftly through trees to catch birds and small mammals mid-air!

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are known for their vibrant green heads and are one of the most common wild ducks.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are one of the few ducks that nest in tree cavities near water.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, using a distinctive V-shaped formation to save energy.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for minutes, patiently hunting fish with their sharp, spear-like beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live over 50 years and absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut faster than human eyes can blink!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can breathe air by gulping from the water's surface during low oxygen conditions.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and use their big mouths to ambush prey!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot in freshwater lakes!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and use ambush tactics to catch prey quickly in freshwater habitats.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs famous for their loud, high-pitched springtime mating calls.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow over 8 inches long, making them one of North Americaâ€™s largest frogs!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump up to 10 times their body length in a single leap!

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and often live near water, making them excellent swimmers in the wild!

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to an hour while hunting fish.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous snakes like rattlesnakes to scare off predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, traveling from North America to central Mexico every year!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have tails that mimic bird feathers, helping them evade predators with clever disguise!

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions, including backward, using their two sets of wings independently.

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings over their body, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open while resting.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates and communicate through unique flashing patterns.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can buzz-pollinate flowers by vibrating their flight muscles to release pollen.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their own body length in a single leap!
